text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Israeli newspapers on Sunday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
JERUSALEM POST
- Two soldiers killed, five wounded by Hizbollah roadside bombs. Blast cuts short promising Israeli army career.
- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Palestinian President Yasser Arafat may meet in bid to conclude talks.
- Oslo peace broker Terje Larsen named to Norwegian cabinet.
- Jihad supporters mark anniversary of Islamic Jihad leader Fathi Shqaqi.
- Israeli Chief Justice Aharon Barak: Yitzhak Rabin's government tried to block wife's indictment.
- Report: German envoy got data on missing Israeli airman Ron Arad.
- Netanyahu's religious brother-in-law says he will move to Hebron.
HAARETZ

- Effort to finish up agreement on Hebron to bring it to the approval of Netanyahu and Arafat today. The clause on "hot pursuit" will be put to a decision of the two leaders because of differences between the two teams.
- Syria criticises Israel's intention to look for oil on the Golan Heights. Infrastructure Ministry: We'll not start drilling on the Golan.
- Committee recommends avoiding subsidised housing in order to prevent Jerusalem from becoming a Haredi city.
- Police will recommend putting on trial settlers who broke into Jericho.
MAARIV
- Political sources say Syrian preparations on Golah Heights clear way for an attack in short time.
- "German broker received guarantees from Iran that Ron Arad is still alive".
- Ron Lauder to compete for control of Africa-Israel company.
- 40 years to massacre of 49 Arabs at Kafr Kassem.
YEDIOTH AHRONOTH
- Netanyahu demands Arafat apologise for jihad speech. U.S. effort to wrap up negotiations before Arafat goes abroad tomorrow.
- Three Jordanians stopped on way to hiding mines on path travelled by Israeli hikers.
- FBI opens office in Tel Aviv.
- From today: a monument at site where Rabin was murdered.
